lines.text: [after a drunken Kid Sheleen shoots at a target on the barn]
He did it! He missed the barn!
Kid, Kid, what a time to fall off the wagon. Look at your eyes.
What's wrong with my eyes?
Well they're red, bloodshot.
You ought to see 'em from my side.
Guns, bottles, fists, knives, clubs - all the same to me. All the same to you?

At first you don't think you can stand to get hit, then you realize you can take it 'cause the blood don't matter, and you know you're gonna live. It's a great gift I'm goin' to give you - to know it don't hurt to fight!
He's a murderer, a hired killer. His nose was bit off in a fight.
If I was gonna be scared, I'd be scared of the fella who bit it off, not him!
Some gang! An Indian ranch hand, a drunken gunfighter, a sex maniac, and an uncle!
I've never seen a man get through a day so fast.
We can't hold up the train.
Why not?
Lots of reasons.
Name 'em.
We're rustlers, not train robbers.
Well, if people didn't try something new, there wouldn't be hardly any progress at all.
Let's have a drink for old times' sake.
Old times' sake? That means you got no cash.
Jackson, what's happening?
It's ghost sickness.
What's that?
In this Indian religion, see, we believe what the gods did when they made a man crazy was they made him fall in love.
Well now, there's a game for a sheriff - liar's poker. We got our unemployed off the street and made Wolf City safe all in one brilliant stroke.

Yeah, it's all over in Dodge. Tombstone, too; Cheyenne, Deadwood, all gone, all dead and gone. Why, the last time I came through Tombstone, the big excitement there was about the new rollerskate rink that they had laid out over the OK Corral. I'll tell you something else, I used to work for the Buffalo Bill Wild West Show and a Congress of Rough Riders. And I rescued many stagecoach passengers from road agents and drunkard injuns... in the nick of time! Twice a day, three times on Saturday.
[to Butch Cassidy and the Hole in the Wall Gang]
Some gang of cutthroats and murderers. We used to whisper your names when we were kids - scared to say them out loud. How sad - you got old.

[singing]
She has the smile of an angel.

[singing]
Fights like the devil.

[singing]
The eyes of an angel.

[singing]
Bites like the devil.

[singing]
The face of an angel.

[singing]
I say, she's the devil.

[singing]
She's mean and evil through and through.
Cat Ballou.
Cat Ballou.

[singing]
She's mean and evil through and through.
Mrs. Parker didn't introduce us, I'm Catherine Ballou.
I'm drunk as a skunk.

[to Cat, on the train]
Ma'am, I apologize for my disgusting condition and I assure you I will not inflict myself on you any further.

[both Sam The Shade and The Sunrise Kid - as narrators/singers]
Round and round and round they went, 'til man and gal and beast were spent. Round and round and round they rode... Oh, what an episode!

[shows her the bedroom on the train]
This is the master bedroom. Do you approve?
Oh, it's swell. A regular Tintoretto!
[Jackson slugs Clay]
Well, what was that for?
Well, everyone else was doin' it. I got the right to share in the fun without regard to race, creed or color according to the Fourteenth Amendment.
Sir Harry Percival, I presume.
Really, roughing it on the frontier - how delightful!
Oh, you like our wide open spaces?
[Cat remove her cape to reveal a very low cut dress]
A little wine with music...
[Sir Harry winds his gramophone]
...a little Nineteenth Century science, Stone Age atmosphere, Cave Man passion...
I thought you were lying.
You mean I wasn't?
[first lines]

[singing]
Well now friends just lend an ear for you're now about to hear the Ballad of Cat Ballou.
What am I gonna do?
They got a gun fighter. You get a gun fighter.

[singing]
Then there came to town, a gun deadly and frightening / A gun quicker than lightening, fasted gun you've seen. / It was the gun in the hand of Eli 'Kid' Sheleen.
[last lines]

[singing]
So she rode away, just where now is a mystery, / But Cat rode into history and her legend grew. / She was the Queen of the outlaws, / Her Highness Cat Ballou. / Cat Ballou, Cat Ballou. / Well, our story now is through.

[singing]
Cat Ballou.

[singing]
Cat Ballou.

[singing]
We'll say farewell to Cat Ballou.
Cut your throat, Cassidy!
a painting on the ceiling!
Oh, yes. That's a Tintoretto.
I'll say it is.
And the first time I ask you to do something for me, like rob one little train!

[sniffs at the faint smell of liquor]
I smell a water hole!
Where are you staying?
On the run, ma'am. Hiding out in a crowd.
You'd like a drink better than a poke in the eye with a sharp stub, wouldn't you?
They're trying to drive him off his ranch! They put manure in his well, they made him talk to lawyers...
[Looks at Frankie Ballou, lying in coffin]
Why is he smiling like that? My father never smiled like that in his whole life?
[looks in coffin again, apalled]
Well, he's going to smile like that forever, now. Courtesy of the Wolf City Development Company.
Ma'am, I can understand your objection to rustlin' - a girl with your background and gentle upbringing - but it's the only way we can raise money.
No it's not.
Well, what do you think we ought to do that's fittin' and proper?
Rob a train.
Build you life anew, ma'am. This studyin' on revenge is just turnin' your back on the future and lettin' the dead past eat at your heart.
I think we'll go to St. Louis.
St. Louis?
Yeah, St. Louis! City on the Missouri, railhead of the Santa Fe, jump off for the Oregon Trail - producers of beef, beer, shoes and, ah, good times.

[singing]
Cat Ballou, wicked through and through / They'll now be hanging Cat Ballou.
What are you doing here?
Looking for you.
But you're an outlaw.
Sure am! Got a price on my head!
Shh...
Twenty five dollars for Jed, thirty five dollars for me. Ha ha!
I want to thank you ma'am for all your help with my nephew and I.
You killed my Father!
Oh, that can't be. He's been sitting right there all morning.
No, I saw him.
He hasn't been out that rocker all morning long.
It's a fact.
Why do you say that?
Just telling the truth.

[singing]
There are tear drops in her heart but they can't make her cry. / There are tear drops in her heart but they can't make her cry. / She's lost all the kin that she's known, and the tears will turn into stone / All the teardrops in her heart, 'cause they can't make her cry.
All right! You all say you love me and are beholden to me, and "take it easy Cat. We're gonna take care of you!"
Come on, jump.
Jump?
Jump!

[to Cat]
Oh, it was just swell! Just the way I figured it'd be.

[to Jackson]
See ya later, son.

[after slugging someone during a brawl]
Sholom Aleichem!
Why do men always think marriage is the only thing on a woman's mind?
Don't call me 'Lo'!
What's your name, so I can vote for you in the next election?
Jackson?
Yeah...?
Oh, Jackson.
You won't make me cry. You'll never make me cry!

[coming home from a drunken brawl]
... and some of them, the very few, Stay pickled 'til they're ninety-twoooo!
[literally falls off the wagon]
Stay here with us. There's somebody trying to kill my father.
No.
Jed...
Jed.
We'll stay, ma'am, it'll be our pleasure to do what we can.
We don't need him them.
I think you do. My Uncle here ain't never shot at a man. It's against his principles.
Is that true?
Oh yes, ma'am, that's true. Neither has he.
But we'll stay and do what we can. As long as there ain't no trouble.
Hold on. ma'am.
Listen, Miss Ballou.
Hit him! Hit him! Hit him!
